item.title: Another Hard Drive
item.dc:creator: BaTz281
item.description:
mattemuse:

you should probably spend more moeny and get a SSDD because they are an improvement in technology. Moore’s law says get a SSDD.

That’s probably not the best idea because of this:

Cameron :smiley: :

So I’m in need of a new hard drive, yet can’t really decide on what to get.

I’ve been told by a few people that the WD Caviar Black 640GB is good (That will be enough space for me), but for $5-10 more you can get the 750GB.

a) What would be the better choice (This drive will have all my Steam games on it, so the faster the better)
b) Are there any other worthwhile options of similar size and price (Around AUD$100)

I’m not sure about Cameron, but my Steam directory is something in the neighborhood of 20GB. Even the smallest (~24GB ) SSD’s are at or over $100US. Considering the loss of capacity due to memory addressing, and the ability to use the drive for more than just Steam, he would need at a least a 128GB SSD, which is pushing $300.

To be sure, they are fast, but I don’t think they fit his requirements.

item.title: Another Hard Drive
item.dc:creator: Jeannotvb
item.description:
BaTz281:

All the above advice is true. Western Digital generally makes great drives (in 14 years of building PCs, I’ve only ever used WD and Maxtor, and [knock on wood] haven’t had a single drive failure). And with magnetic 7200RPM drives, the cost per gigabyte is so cheap nowadays, as you noticed - you can add an extra 110GB for only $5-10.

I would warn against RAID0 unless you have a reliable and frequent backup system - even if the drives themselves don’t fail, RAID controllers, driver issues, etc. can all affect a RAID. I’m not saying they don’t perform well (used to run two separate RAID0 arrays in my machines, they are fast) but the failure consequences are high. RAID0+1 helps in this regard, but you’re only looking to get 1 drive so we can forget about that

Bottom line - definitely go with a WD, and then, definitely go for the Caviar Black with the highest cache available. Whether you get Sata 3.0 or Sata 6.0 is up to you and your motherboard specs, but capacity is up to you

This guy is a winner.

Yeah it’s a major weakness of RAID 0. I would suggest only to use it if you’re going to work with a lot of big files (I don’t like waiting half an hour for a huge file to copy on my HDD).
